title: FontLab 5 released for Windows
content:
We have finally managed to kick FontLab Studio 5 (at least the Windows version) out of the nest. Cool new stuff includes:

- _ **Autotrace** _ is now included in the product. No need to go outside Fontlab to trace glyphs.  
 - Many new _ **printing and proofing** _ features, making it easy to get printouts at all stages of the font production process.  
 - _ **RoboFab** _ python library is now included in FontLab. Users get access to the Universal Font Object (.ufo) XML font format and to a bunch of improved python resources.  
 - New, improved _ **metrics window** _ incorporates a powerful new table that makes class-based kerning a snap and has a multi-line and context-based preview window so users can see how spacing and kerning will actually look in text without having to generate the whole font and print out samples.  
 - Support for _ **Unicode 3.2 and 4.0** _ means that users have access to virtually every character in Unicode.

The new price is US$649 and upgrades from FL4.6 go for US$99. A Macintosh version is also in the works and will enter beta testing shortly.

More details available at:  
 [http://www.fontlab.com/The-News/Announcements/FontLab-Studio-5-for-Windo...](http://web.archive.org/web/20071211191009/http:/www.fontlab.com/The-News/Announcements/FontLab-Studio-5-for-Windows/ "http://www.fontlab.com/The-News/Announcements/FontLab-Studio-5-for-Windows/")

Regards,  
Ted Harrison  
Fontlab Ltd.

Paul, can you draw anykind of point and then change it (using the menu bar)? what about Clean Up Paths or Optimize?

Download the demo yourself and check it out:  
 [http://www.fontlab.com/Font-tools/FontLab-Studio/](http://web.archive.org/web/20071211191009/http:/www.fontlab.com/Font-tools/FontLab-Studio/ "http://www.fontlab.com/Font-tools/FontLab-Studio/")
I have mac. thank you anyway.

_Can you draw anykind of point and then change it (using the menu bar)?_

You mean change the kind of point you just made, or change the next kind of point you will make? If the latter, you can switch between different kinds of new points using either the toolbar of keyboard shortcuts. If you have already, for instance, made a corner point, and decide you want it to be a tangent you can covert the line on one side of it to a curve by alt+clicking on it, and then convert the point by double clicking on it. You don’t need to change tools during this operation: the operations available are contextual based on where you click.

\> You mean change the kind of point you just made

Yes. And even if you draw a circle; you go to Menu \> Points \> Curve/Corner/Tangent. am i clear?

If you’ve drawn a circle, you can only toggle between curve or corner point (by double-clicking on the node). You can’t have a tangent point unless there is a straight line on one side of the point and a curve on the other. The double-clicking is contextual: if you have a corner point with curves on either side, double-clicking on it will make it a curve point. If you have a corner point with a curve on one side and a straight line on the other side, double-clicking will make it a tangent. If you have a corner point with a straight line on both sides, double-clicking won’t do anything, since there is no curve element to define a curve or tangent. So point type is dependent on adjacent line type, which is how it should be I think.
